message: And of course the complimentary topic :)
Fork Queue.
the fork queue doesnt really get in the way though

I can't think of anything that gets in the way. But fork queues rarely work, and offer nothing a simple `git pull` would. I'm all for helping scm be as simple as possible for a user, but I think the Fork Queue does more harm than good.
as someone who only knows basic git, I have no idea what the fork queue actually does
I think that speaks to its uselessness
I have a hard time figuring out Fork Queue as well
The fork queue could be good, but it would be a decent amount of work. That said, if there's no interest within github for doing that work, I say just remove it. It's not useful in its current state.
The sad kitty against the red background @ status.github.com   .... sorry, I had to.

I must be the only one who uses the fork queue. It's an easy way to get a commit from a fork pulled in and has always worked for me. I don't want to see it go. But pull requests make it less valuable.
I personally would like to see Messages removed. I don't like having yet another inbox, and almost every one of them I'd rather see added as an issue to my project.
Messages I'm actually okay with.  Notifications as a separate notion I take issue with.
Combine the two inboxes (preferably with flagging / tagging / user-definable differentiation).
yes, combine Messages and Notifications, and make it so that when you click on the notification to open it, a trackback happens which marks it as read
Sorry, my fault. You see, notifications should really be reworked. ;)

@koraktor As far as I can tell, I can disable receiving emails (which I have done), but not the notification itself (so I still have a load of unread notifications on Github itself; which I would use "Mark all as read" for, but more often than not I have other notifications in the mix as well).
Remove notifications for successful page builds - I only need to know if it's been unsuccessful.
The LAG
@koraktor You can't disable the GitHub notification, only the emailed one.
Funny, all of these are things you want added.
Heh, it's funny.. I never find myself using the horizontal navigation bar (My Actions, Pull Requests)
Programmers are such a fickle bunch.
fwiw, I like the fork queue
Remove the fixed-ness of the markup. And image gradients on buttons (use CSS gradients, it's 2011 and your audience is developers, not IE6 users)

The watched repo feature is useless to me as it is. Most GitHub users I know just use bookmarks and avoid watching repos as they quickly clutter up the landing page. GitHub should remove it and then re-think it's purpose.
@MarkBennett I like Messages in that I can contact developers on GitHub. However, I think displaying an e-mail or a hidden e-mail (like Craigslist) would be better for that.

@rbates +1 for the removal of messages. I always read them in my email and just automatically clear them from my GitHub inbox. Keep the notifications for pull requests and system notifications such as page builds.
@MarkBennett I think the 'easy' solution is what most people have suggested. either introduce stars like the gists or something to that extent
@MarkBennett I use watched repo's extensively, as having 140-something bookmarks added to the 500-ish I already have is going to make the situation even worse
Perhaps what's needed is an option to include activity from a watched repo or not when clicking "watch"
plus I believe the watched repo's links into the search box, so repo's which I previously know of are accessible from any github page
@steveivy agreed, I have different levels of interest in different repos. Most I just watch so I can find it again later, but others I'm interested in contributing and want to see all activity.

@rbates CodeShelver (http://codeshelver.com/shelf) is good for the "remember it later" kind of repos and it does integrate itself pretty well into GitHub when you install the extension... though native support for the same idea would be better.
for instance, the conversation in https://convore.com/github/awesome-ruby-gems-on-github
I want to follow the majority of those gems to broaden my toolkit, but I would only like commit activity on them as I am not too bothered about issues/pull requests as I am not actually using them

yes, having "levels" of information about watched repo's would be very useful, for instance, having all activity on your "main" auth system and only commit activity on your "backup" auth system libraries
wow I love that idea @steveiyy :D
@kneath, it's not an attack, just a piece of advice :)

@kneath, the whole point of this is the performance. Image gradient = extra HTTP request… And on Linux (where fonts suck) that “experience” was terrible: buttons were split into two parts with these wide ass fonts and the gradient looked really bad. BTW, that's more about fixed widths
Does it really matter...?
See, the sad panda flat non-gradient button?
I guess that's where I come back to delivering a great experience rather than focusing on implementation, it makes you focus on the wrong things
if you are a member of several organization, there's a "Switch Context" on the dashboard
I also seem to find myself clicking the "wrong" link in the News Feed (e.g. for a new issue), more often than the "right" one.
That's an older release on the screenshot
@kneath To be fair, GitHub is exceptionally minimalist. I doubt there's much/anything one would really want taken out.
Sorry, I just hate CSS3 trolls. Build awesome experiences, use modern best practices, but focus on the experience not the implementation
Well, forgive me if I don't believe you since our primary browser on linux is Firefox, which still doesn't support CSS gradients :)
The firefox version distributed on Ubuntu at least
@kneath we just have the ability to take a bad thing and spin it into a good thing
@myfreeweb Our buttons have been using CSS gradients for almost a year now, not sure why you feel the need to personally attack us
Also, all of these are still feature *requests* :)
You guys are impossible
@kneath it also shows you are doing something right :D
Yes, it does. But the latest version distributed to Ubuntu is less than that
Ha

The biggest annoyances I have tend to be around Notifications and Messages.  One of them is a redundant interface, and getting the things you've already read marked as such seems more difficult than it needs to be.
@myfreeweb: Well, our buttons have been using CSS gradients since May 24. Perhaps you didn't notice because we focus on the experience rather than bragging about HTML5/CSS3-ness of our site :)
@kneath, in Ubuntu fonts are (almost) fine. I was using Arch with no good fonts… well, anyway, I use Mac OS X most of the time :-)
Really? Natty alpha 3 has Firefox 4. Maverick has 3.6, as far as I know
@micrypt, actually, no
contexts?
I spend half my day scheming of ways to take features out
BTW, Firefox supports CSS gradients since 3.6
http://share.kyleneath.com/captures/Ubuntu_64-bit-20110310-141727.png
I've always found contexts very confusing and would like a different approach… but it's not something you just can remove, so I guess that's not valid either. this is a tricky question!
In any case we have css gradients on all our buttons and have for quite some time
If you're not thinking about what to remove from your product, I don't think your'e doing your customers service
Adding features is easy, removing them is hard
I always forget 'your actions' is available on the homepage. I always look at my own profile to see that.
oh right i know what you mean
@kneath Well, I suspect the time spent on that's going to increase with time. Your scheming's paying off. ^^
And we appreciate it!
@kneath btw, you guys at GitHub are doing a great job! Don't get discouraged. I love GitHub and recommend it to everyone I know. I complain because I care. Or something like that! :P
Well, there's a reason I created these topics, I do want to hear what you guys have to say

The only hurdle I could see doing it would be that I would have to get an account on Lighthouse, configure a project with my account, come back to GitHub, and try to connect the two.  Or vice-versa with Lighthouse trying to connect to GitHub
Like possibly making it push-button complete to integrate Lighthouse into the repo, or Redmine, or something.
Make that dead simple and I wouldn't even miss the issue tracker

I guess my interest would be if instead of rolling your own issue tracker, you made it dead simple to integrate with something that was focused on providing as good of an issue tracker experience as you do with Git.

I for one wouldn't mind if the issue tracker went away entirely, to be replaced with either a simple to-do list or some partnership or deep-integration with a product who's focus was making great issue tracking, like JIRA, Bugzilla, Redmine or the host of other options.
remove the hashtag navigation in the issue tracker, it's half-done and doesn't support going back into history properly
Remove the inbox. Just do it.
@lericson Seconded
@rbates agreed. Messages aren't useful.
@kneath remove gem building

Annoying notifications: "Your page has been built. If this is the first time you've pushed, it may take a few minutes to appear, otherwise your changes should appear immediately.". Just notify me then it fails!
Timeline. It's useless but could be great if improved
Stars on gists. :)
@klauern I personally can't stand Lighthouse issue tracker. I much prefer the built-in one even though it does need a lot of work.
@rbates What about doing what was done with Jekyll and Gollum: spin it off into it's own project?  That way the community could at least try to improve it more organically.
project graphs (impact, punchcard, traffic)
@bryckbost I think the traffic graph is pretty useful
I'm on the inbox removal team as well. Specifically, I want less places to check.
+1 inbox, just send the messages to our email...
^ Forgot "exactly one thing."

Remove seperation from notifications/messages/commit comments. Group them together and make them useful and faster. Remove huge wide list in the Inbox view and bright exposed icons and highlighting. Remove barriers from quick conversation and collaboration by making it easier to jump in and out of a conversation. More like an IM/Wave/Facebook Feed and less like a list of static content. It'd be nice if people used GitHub to communicate more about code directly, so it's actually 'social coding'  more than 'social sharing of code'.

Looking at the Fork Queue, there isn't any documentation for it that I can see, and for new people to Git it might not make any sense.
My idea is create an option to disable it in /admin, so people who want the feature/understand the feature can keep it. Either that, or a pretty shiny docset like the Bootcamp would be helpful
@kennethreitz fair point on the traffic graph. The rest can go.
@atomicules You can disable that: https://github.com/account/notifications
